title: How did religion impact early Chinese history? - Quora

response.answer_text: What is your definition of a “religion”? I’m not here to debate semantics, but it’s relevant to bring this up since it might disqualify what I’m about to say. For most of its history, China was a caesaropapist state in which the emperor reigned supreme (pun intended) over each and every religious leader except for the worship of the emperor himself, making the imperial cult the most impactful religion in Chinese history since the First Emperor. The English translation emperor, however, loses much of the nuances in huangdi (皇帝), which is the Chinese title of emperorship compounded from huang (皇), which came from the Three Sovereigns who were said to be “god-kings,” and di (帝), which stood for the Five Divine Rulers in Chinese mythology. In other words, huangdi the emperor of China himself was the undisputed living god on Earth. Some sinologists have started to translate this title as the “thearch,” but it’s a bit too late as “emperor” has been the default translation for years. Actually, in a way you can also flip the coin and say that imperial China was in fact a theocracy under the cult of huangdi.
